top_comment.text:
Screenwriter Eric Roth (Forrest Gump, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button) 
takes viewers inside his creative process in an exploration of where he 
gets his ideas.

http://bit.ly/EricRoth﻿
top_comment.author: Oscars

comments.text: Forget the typo... keep coming out with videos like this.
comments.author: AJ Foslom

captions.text:
Roth:
WHAT MAKES ONE PERSON,

YOU KNOW,
"MORE CREATIVE" THAN ANOTHER?
I THINK WE'RE ALL CREATIVE.

IT'S JUST
I WAS GIVEN THIS SOMETHING --

I GUESS SOME ARROGANCE
AND SELF-CONFIDENCE --

THAT I'M ABLE TO ARTICULATE IT,
YOU KNOW, THAT I THINK,

"I'M GONNA DO THIS.
IT'S GONNA BE FUCKING GOOD."
I'M VERY DISCIPLINED.

I THINK
YOU HAVE TO BE DISCIPLINED.
I MEAN, I KNOW THERE'S PEOPLE

WHO SOMETIMES
CAN DO IT DIFFERENT WAYS

WHERE THEY JUST VOMIT IT OUT
IN THREE WEEKS OR WHATEVER,

BUT THIS IS THE WAY
I HAVE TO DO IT.

THAT'S MY PROCESS.
IT'S JUST, IN A GOOD WAY, A JOB.
I LOOK FORWARD TO IT.

NORMAL DAY IS FOR ME,
I'LL GET UP 5:30 OR SO,

AND I GO TAKE A WALK,
GET SOME EXERCISE.

AND THEN I'LL START
PROBABLY BY 7:30, 8:00,

AND THEN I'LL WORK
TILL LIKE NOON.
THAT'S ABOUT IT.

I CAN ONLY DO
ABOUT FOUR HOURS CREATIVELY.

AND THEN I'LL START AGAIN
AT NIGHT,
AND IF I'M UP AGAINST IT,

I'LL WRITE TILL
THE MIDDLE OF NIGHT, USUALLY.

IF I HAVE ANYTHING I HAVE LEFT
FROM THE NIGHT BEFORE
THAT I'M EXCITED ABOUT,

I CAN'T WAIT TO GET
TO IT THE NEXT MORNING

'CAUSE IT'S JUST SITTING THERE.
I KNOW I'VE SOLVED THAT PROBLEM.

I NEVER LIKED
GOING TO AN OFFICE.
I ACTUALLY HAD AN OFFICE

THAT THE STUDIO
WAS GENEROUS ENOUGH TO GIVE ME,

AND I WENT IN ONCE, AND I HAD IT
FOR LIKE THREE YEARS.
I NEVER WENT IN.

THAT POOR GIRL
WAS SO LONELY IN THERE.

I ALWAYS START AT PAGE ONE
EVERY DAY

'CAUSE I THINK IT'S A SERIES
OF I CALL, LIKE, "EROSION."
YOU HAVE TO KEEP REFILLING,

AND I THINK YOU'RE
ALWAYS IMPROVING IT THAT WAY.

I WORK
ON AN OLD COMPUTER PROGRAM

THAT'S NOT EVEN IN EXISTENCE
ANYMORE THAT I'VE JUST --

HALF SUPERSTITION
AND HALF FEAR OF CHANGE.

SO, HERE COMES -- THIS IS
A DOS PROGRAM KICKING IN.
SO NOW I'M IN DOS,

AND THERE'S NOBODY WHO CAN GET
ON THE INTERNET AND GET THIS.
I HAVE TO GIVE THEM A HARD COPY.

THEY HAVE TO SCAN IT AND THEN
PUT IT IN THEIR COMPUTERS,

AND THEN I WORK THROUGH THEIR
COMPUTER 'CAUSE YOU CAN'T --

YOU CAN'T E-MAIL MINE
OR ANYTHING,

AND YOU CAN'T
GET INTO THE PROGRAM
EXCEPT FOR JUST WHERE IT IS.

IT HAS 40 PAGES,
THEN IT RUNS OUT OF MEMORY.

BUT I LIKE IT
'CAUSE IT MAKES YOU MAKE ACTS.

SO IF I HAVEN'T SAID IT
IN 40 PAGES,

I'M STARTING TO GET IN TROUBLE,
YOU KNOW.

I REALIZED AFTER AWHILE
THE STUDIOS

OR WHOEVER
YOU'RE WRITING IT FOR,

THEY GET ENRAGED AT YOU
FOR BEING LATE.

AND THEN
THEY KIND OF FORGET ABOUT IT.
SO THEY GO THROUGH THESE --

I CALLED IT, YOU KNOW,
STAGES OF DEATH.
YOU KNOW, THEY GRIEVE.

THEY GRIEVE, THEY GET ANGRY,
THEN THEY GRIEVE,

AND THEY COME
EVENTUALLY TO SOME ACCEPTANCE,
AND THE POINT AND THE TRUTH

IS THAT EVENTUALLY,
THEY FORGET ABOUT IT

AND THEY MOVE ON
WITH THEIR LIVES.

THEN THEY GET IT,
AND IF IT'S GOOD, THEY'RE HAPPY.

YOU KNOW, IF IT'S NOT GOOD,
THEY'RE NOT HAPPY.

YOU KNOW, IT'S, LIKE,
BAD TO BE SLOW AND UNPRODUCIBLE,

BUT IT'S NOT SO BAD
TO BE SLOW AND PRODUCIBLE, SO...

I'M MOSTLY INTERESTED --
USUALLY, I CHOSE THE THINGS I DO

AS TO WHAT
THE THEME OF THE PIECE IS,

AS TO WHAT
WILL RESONATE FROM IT,

WHAT WILL HAVE SOMETHING,
HOPEFULLY, THAT WILL LAST.
I THINK THEY COME FROM --

I'M A BIG READER,
VORACIOUS KIND OF READER.

I READ LIKE THREE BOOKS A WEEK,
SO I GET ALL THESE --
SORT OF BOMBARDED BY THINGS.

AND SOME THINGS STICK,
SOME THINGS DON'T.
IT MAKES ME FEEL FULL.

I HAD A DREAM ABOUT THE MOON
AND THAT EXACT IMAGE,

ABOUT THAT ASTRONAUT
WITH THAT ROVER.
AND I WOKE UP, AND I CAME IN

IN, LIKE,
THE MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT.

I WENT ON THE NASA, AND I BOUGHT
THIS AUTOGRAPHED PHOTOGRAPH
FROM THEM TO SEND TO ME.
I WOKE UP THE NEXT MORNING.

HE HAD DIED THAT NIGHT,
THAT ASTRONAUT.
AND THERE WAS NO REASON.

I HADN'T HEARD ANYTHING
ABOUT THE MOON OR ANYTHING.

IS THAT WEIRD?
THAT ONE WAS WEIRD TO ME.

THE SUBJECT MATTER
IS ALWAYS PROBABLY FIRST TO ME,

AND THEN THE CHARACTERS
AND HOW THE CHARACTERS

THEN RELATE
TO THE THEME OF THE PIECE.

MANY YEARS AGO, I DID SOME
REWRITING FOR MICHAEL CIMINO,

AND I WROTE A SCRIPT
FOR MICHAEL CIMINO.

AND MICKEY ROURKE
SHOWED ME THIS WALLET

THAT MICHAEL CIMINO
HAD PREPARED FOR HIM

THAT HAD EVERYTHING THAT
THIS CHARACTER WOULD HAVE --

A DRIVER'S LICENSE,
PLUS FAMILY PICTURES OF PEOPLE,

PEOPLE YOU'RE NEVER GONNA SEE
OR ANYTHING,

AND HIS DRAFT CARD,
EVERYTHING ELSE.

BUT I THOUGHT,
"THAT'S PRETTY ACCURATE

ABOUT WHAT A GOOD WRITER
SHOULD BE."

HE SHOULD KNOW ALL THOSE THINGS
ABOUT THAT PERSON'S LIFE --
IF YOU NEVER USE THEM --

AND EVERY CHARACTER
IN YOUR PIECE AS BEST YOU CAN.
AND PSYCHOLOGICALLY, ALSO.

I START BELIEVING
THESE PEOPLE ARE REAL, YOU KNOW,
IN A GOOD WAY.

I MEAN, I'M NOT
BUILDING CASTLES IN THE SKY

AND MOVING IN THEM,
PARTICULARLY.

BUT THE FUN PART OF WRITING,
OBVIOUSLY,

IS FINDING OUT ALONG THE WAY
WHO ARE THE PEOPLE.

I KNOW HE HAD A WIFE, I KNOW
HE HAD CHILDREN, THE WIFE DIED.

I MEAN, WHATEVER IS HIS
LIFE'S STORY BECOMES POPULATED,
YOU KNOW.
NO WRITER'S BLOCK. NEVER HAD IT.
IF I DO FIND I'M SORT OF, LIKE,

SEEMINGLY NOT GOING ANYWHERE
WITH SOMETHING,
I CHANGE THE WEATHER.

I MAKE IT, LIKE, RAIN,
AND ALL OF A SUDDEN,

YOU HAVE A DIFFERENT
POINT OF VIEW OF THE SCENE.
IT'S RAINING OUT, YOU KNOW,

AND ALL OF A SUDDEN,
IT FEELS DIFFERENT, YOU KNOW.

THE TRUTH IS, IF I WAS
GONNA REALLY ANALYZE MYSELF,

I'M PROBABLY
A FRUSTRATED NOVELIST, YOU KNOW,

BUT NEVER HAD THE GUTS
TO WRITE A NOVEL.

I THINK, ALSO,
THAT I'VE ALWAYS --
AT LEAST WHEN I GREW UP,

MOVIES WERE THE CULTURAL CENTER
OF THE UNIVERSE.

I WOULD DO IT --
I REALLY WOULD DO IT ANYWAYS.

I MEAN, I DID IT
WHEN I DIDN'T HAVE TWO CENTS.

AND I LOVED THAT,
YOU KNOW, CORNY, TRITE THING

SITTING IN THE DARK ROOM
WITH THIS THING

THAT'S BIGGER THAN LIFE,
YOU KNOW,

AND HOW THOSE THINGS
CAN STAY WITH YOU

IN SOME REALLY
TREMENDOUSLY PRIMAL WAY.
